this last weekend i went on a lovely trip to urlLink San Francisco with Sam, urlLink Cuong and Darren. As you can see from the photos, it was quite an experience. But then there's the fact that i got attcked on the streets of Castro by a disgruntled dude wearing all red. "What are you looking at, pale-ass bitch?" he posed right before he shoved me backwards. Before i knew it, i had been punched in the face and head about four times by Mr. Red. Sam noticed i was under attack and came to my rescue, distracting Red long enough for me to catch my balance. Sam took a few blows to the face. Then, Red's mysteriously cute accomplice who'd remained in the woodwork until now, tried to snatch my silver beanie from my head. It wasn't until that moment that i snapped into the reality that i was being attacked. Until then, it was a fast blur of confusion and disbelief. I grabbed my hat from shaved-headed-gangster no.2 and was able to dodge and block a few punches and run away toward the crowd. I looked to find Sam and he was safe -- and he immediately got all of us into a cab to escape. Because i was drunk with KettleOne and hopped on adrenaline, i was not in pain immediately. Sam, Darren, Coung and I all went back to our pad at Page&Pierce and drank a bit more and chatted out our experience. The prescient irony ofo the entire situation is still unfolding, but i can already relay that my friend Brian Loftin in Dallas TX was composing an e-mail to me during the time of the attack. It was a narrative he unexplainably wanted to share with me about the time he was gay bashed in 2000. I was stunned to see that in my inbox the next morning. More prominently was the fact that I asked Sam either the night before or during the day before the attack if he had ever been in a fist fight. My head had been filled with that vision -- remotely -- for a few days. I've been consciously trying to improve my perception and recognition of the visions and feelings that i have ultimately identified as my intuition or psychic ability. this is a painful lesson that i should try harder. the attack was compeletely random. unprovoked. it was not a gay bashing, i don't think, because these guys were seemingly gay. gangsters, but gay. yes, grandpa, those do exist. so the next day i was sore and groggy, but blamed it on the vodka, not my soon-to-be diagnosed concussion. since the time of the attack at about 2 am Sunday morning, i've been dizzy, not myself and a bit confused. I walked into my kitchen to grab a glass from the cupboard to for some water. instead of opening the cabinet, i tried instead to open my freezer door -- from the wrong side -- for about ten seconds. weird. and i had a witness. I went to work Tuesday and was not feeling well at all. I had no patience and everyone was getting on my nerves. i also was very unrproductive, despite the fact there's so much to do. at the urging of my concerned boss and the director of my department, i took the last hour of work off and saw a doctor Wednesday at lunch. He said my brain was still a bit swolen from the attack. My right side the worst from the points of hardest impact. The left side from when those blows bounced my brain from the left-lining of my brain. he said my dizziness and confusion could last up to six weeks. my friends have been very supportive in this time of craziness. although it seems less crazy by the day. violence sucks. i will be fine.

This is what my parents didn't want published in my hometown newspaper: As a gay person growing up in Freeport, I was always ashamed. I kept my secret from everyone -- my parents, my closest friends and even myself. I prayed nightly for God to save me from what I had always been taught was a sin. It wasn't until I moved away to go to college in Austin that I realized I could be myself and live a normal, productive and fulfilling life like everyone else. Being gay, for the first time in my life, didn't matter to anyone. That's why I was delighted to see your editorial in The Facts, which I read regularly online from my new home in West Hollywood, California. It's very important for the people of Brazoria County to know that gay and lesbian people are an important part of the community. By extending the same rights to these law abiding citizens that everyone else takes for granted, the community will be better served. Logic and history tells us that the coupling of two loving people to establish a home and family is of great benefit to society. Denying these same rights to gay people -- who already have families and partnerships of equal value to their heterosexual counterparts -- is counterintuitive. Our families and relationships deserve the same protections and responsibilities as any other under the law. I hope readers of The Facts will not succumb to the fear tactics being espoused by certain religious organizations that claim to speak for God. Gay marriage will not lead to polygamy. It will not lead to people marrying animals. It will not lead to the destruction of civilization as we know it. Just think about it. As we continue this discussion as a nation -- and as a community -- let's be sure and remember that the debate is not in the abstract and theoretical -- it affects the everyday lives of millions in this country. There are human beings at the heart of this matter. The most patriotic thing we can do is embrace the Constitution in its true spirit and refuse to sit idly by when some in this country, at the expense of your fellow citizens, use it as a tool of discrimination.

I bit the bullet and did laundry today. It had been way too long. But the fun part, as you will see, is that i got to play with my new picture phonen while i was there -- which enables me to bring my adventures to you in a new enhanced way! I know you will be checking back here with more frequency now, for sure. As you can see, there's a lot more happening at the corner of santa monica blvd. and genesee than laundry. the ol' golden rule liquor store always proves to be the perfect place for anything you may need. the cashier there has three teeth but is jolly as all hell. maybe it's all the liquor behind him, maybe it's the fact that he just doesn't give a damn. i will have to take a snap shot of him to share with you later. I also picked up a bottle of Fiji water while i was there. It's so damn tasty i can hardly stand it. They bottle it over by Fiji, of course, and accordingn to the bottle, there's a reason for that. "The origin of FIJI water is rainfall, which over decades filters into an aquifer deep beneath volcanic highlands and pristine tropical forrest on the main island of Viti Levu in Fiji. Separated by over 1,500 miles of the open Pacific from the nearest continent, this virgin ecosystem protects one of the purest waters in the world. Thirsty? I was. But the adventures don't stop there. There are always a variety of intersting folks hanging out at the laundromat. This family, for example, arrived during my first smoke break. I took this photo without their knowledge. I think that may be illegal, but maybe not. Anyhow, what i didn't see at first was the fact that they had brought their pet with them. A Bird! He was very well trained -- or at least keenly aware that his wings had been clipped and he was not flying anywhere . AND he didn't shit on anyone while he was there. And another thing i find peticularly peculiar -- in a wierd double entendre sort of way. The names of the washers and dryers remind me of a few of my druggie friends. This would make a good inside joke in a gay film. You read it hear first. You speed queen, you. Come to think of it, doing laundry is not such a bad thing. I think what sucks the most for me is that i have to pack all my dirtly clothes into my car and drive to the damn place, then pack them up and bring them home. I used to have a washer and dryer when I lived in Texas. Then i gave it to my brother who lived in austin -- and when he came home to live with mommy and daddy again while he teaches at the very high school from which i graduated, they sit unused in the garage. Anyhow, i need to hop in the shower and head over to a friend's place to stay the night. Then tomorrow it's off to Sam's house for poolside cocktails and rooftop firework viewing. Oh, America. Come back! Come back!

As Bush worked to provide the vaporware implementation of 9/11 Commissioners' reccomendation to have a national director of intelligence, he addressed questions of this person's authority and accountability with the following: "Well, I don't think the person ought to be a member of my cabinet. I will hire the person and I can fire the person, which is - any president would like. I'll tell you, that's how you have accountability in government." - George W. Bush NYT . I am just curious why this is not getting more play -- not in the context of the current creation of an 'intelligence czar' -- but in the innumerable failures in Iraq, Afghanistan, and the Homeland. There's been no accountability. No one has been "fired." I suppose it's up to all of us to fire Mr. Bush in November.
